subject: Re: [junit] Do JUnit internals suck?!?

messageBody:
johannes.akinlaja@... wrote:
> Hi Berin,
>
> if I got you right, you want TestCase to be an interface. One of the
> reasons is:
>
> Berin Loritsch wrote:
>
>>The reason being that sometimes the semantics and internals of the
>>way TestCase is written gets in the way of how I want to make JUnit
>>work in my environment.
>
>
> I never had such problems due to TestCase being a class. Could you give an
> example?

Part of this comes from my Component Based Design background. An
interface is a document of contracts. Your contracts are always with
the interface. The reason for it is so that the implementations can
change wildly without breaking the contracts. Version 4 of JUnit would
be able to work with Version 1 code if the contracts remain the same.
That is not always the case with an object hierarchy.

The problem with altering behavior based on a class hierarchy in the
way that JUnit does it is that it is neither polymorphic, nor interface
based. It is somewhere in the middle--which is not clear. Altering the
behavior of a TestCollector based on the TestCase/TestSuite
implementations means that if I had my own implementation of the Test
interface I don't know how it is going to be handled. Interfaces do
not require you to have the same base class. When used properly, that
is a definite *strength*. When used improperly, it causes problems
in predictability.

My point is that the contracts with the Test interface are not defined
clearly enough. If I have to write a test harness (which I do BTW) that
works quite differently than the core JUnit TestCase, then I am SOL. I
can't take advantage of any of the features that I would otherwise be
able to expect with the relationship between TestCase and TestSuite. I
might be able to have a bunch of individual Test objects--which in some
cases might be even better, but my objects would not be treated the same
as the TestCase/TestSuite.

For instance, I need to have a setup where I instantiate a component
container, and the tests. I want the tests to automatically collect all
the testXXXX() methods and execute them. However I can't do that unless
I extend TestCase. I can't extend TestCase because of other mitigating
circumstances.

Lastly, when your contracts are fixated with the *interface* and not the
abstract class, you do not depend on the internals of the abstract
class. There are some of those dependencies. Logic for running a test
should not be included in the TestCase itself. The only thing that
should be in a TestCase are the individual testXXX() methods and
possibly the setUp()/tearDown() methods.
